docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser article on her sampling of absinthe, the herb- and wormwood-flavored liqueur, and cocktails made with it at several London bars; says absinthe fad appears to be waning; it began in 1998 when it was discovered that absinthe had never been legally banned in Britain, as it is in most of Western Europe and US; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the decades since it was banned, absinthe, a spirit flavored with anise and wormwood, has been inflated with tremendous allure. It was said to make people wickedly drunk and to unleash the creativity in their souls. It was hedonism distilled into a liqueur the color of a pea leaf. Absinthe was also supposed to be hallucinogenic and was blamed for causing insanity, which is why it was banned in most of Western Europe and the United States. Then in 1998, a group of curious Londoners uncovered a surprising detail: absinthe had never been legally banned in Britain. They soon began importing it. It was an instant hit among the young bar crowd.
